trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Cloud Services and ASP.NET | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Cloud Services and ASP.NET | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a multi-tier app using ASP.NET MVC and Azure. The app runs in a cloud service, with web role and worker role. It uses Entity Framework, SQL Database, and Azure Storage queues and blobs.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a multi-tier app using ASP.NET MVC and Azure. The app runs in a cloud service, with web role and worker role. It uses Entity Framework, SQL Database, and Azure Storage queues and blobs.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to create a multi-tier .NET application with an ASP.NET MVC front-end, and deploy it to an <linkText>Azure cloud service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to create a multi-tier .NET application with an ASP.NET MVC front-end, and deploy it to an <linkText>Azure cloud service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The application uses <linkText>Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title>, the <linkText>Azure Blob service</linkText><title></title>, and the <linkText>Azure Queue service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The application uses <linkText>Azure SQL Database</linkText><title></title>, the <linkText>Azure Blob service</linkText><title></title>, and the <linkText>Azure Queue service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can <linkText>download the Visual Studio project</linkText><title></title> from the MSDN Code Gallery.
trans-unit.target: You can <linkText>download the Visual Studio project</linkText><title></title> from the MSDN Code Gallery.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial shows you how to build and run the application locally, how to deploy it to Azure and run in the cloud, and finally how to build it from scratch.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial shows you how to build and run the application locally, how to deploy it to Azure and run in the cloud, and finally how to build it from scratch.

trans-unit.source: You can start by building from scratch and then do the test and deploy steps afterward if you prefer.
trans-unit.target: You can start by building from scratch and then do the test and deploy steps afterward if you prefer.

trans-unit.source: The application is an advertising bulletin board.
trans-unit.target: The application is an advertising bulletin board.

trans-unit.source: Users create an ad by entering text and uploading an image.
trans-unit.target: Users create an ad by entering text and uploading an image.

trans-unit.source: They can see a list of ads with thumbnail images, and they can see the full size image when they select an ad to see the details.
trans-unit.target: They can see a list of ads with thumbnail images, and they can see the full size image when they select an ad to see the details.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Ad list</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Ad list</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The application uses the <linkText>queue-centric work pattern</linkText><title></title> to off-load the CPU-intensive work of creating thumbnails to a back-end process.
trans-unit.target: The application uses the <linkText>queue-centric work pattern</linkText><title></title> to off-load the CPU-intensive work of creating thumbnails to a back-end process.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to run both front-end and back-end in an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to run both front-end and back-end in an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: An alternative is to run the front-end in an <linkText>Azure website</linkText><title></title> and use the <linkText>WebJobs</linkText><title></title> feature (currently in preview) for the back-end.
trans-unit.target: An alternative is to run the front-end in an <linkText>Azure website</linkText><title></title> and use the <linkText>WebJobs</linkText><title></title> feature (currently in preview) for the back-end.

trans-unit.source: For a tutorial that uses WebJobs, see <linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a tutorial that uses WebJobs, see <linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to choose the services that best fit your scenario, see <linkText>Azure Websites, Cloud Services, and virtual machines comparison</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to choose the services that best fit your scenario, see <linkText>Azure Websites, Cloud Services, and virtual machines comparison</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: How to enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: How to enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: How to create a Visual Studio cloud service project with an ASP.NET MVC web role and a worker role.
trans-unit.target: How to create a Visual Studio cloud service project with an ASP.NET MVC web role and a worker role.

trans-unit.source: How to test the cloud service project locally, using the Azure storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: How to test the cloud service project locally, using the Azure storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: How to publish the cloud project to an Azure cloud service and test using an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: How to publish the cloud project to an Azure cloud service and test using an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: How to upload files and store them in the Azure Blob service.
trans-unit.target: How to upload files and store them in the Azure Blob service.

trans-unit.source: How to use the Azure Queue service for communication between tiers.
trans-unit.target: How to use the Azure Queue service for communication between tiers.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes that you understand basic concepts about Azure cloud services such as web role and worker role terminology.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes that you understand basic concepts about Azure cloud services such as web role and worker role terminology.

trans-unit.source: It also assumes that you know how to work with <linkText>ASP.NET MVC</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Web Forms</linkText><title></title> projects in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: It also assumes that you know how to work with <linkText>ASP.NET MVC</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Web Forms</linkText><title></title> projects in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: The sample application uses MVC, but most of the tutorial also applies to Web Forms.
trans-unit.target: The sample application uses MVC, but most of the tutorial also applies to Web Forms.

trans-unit.source: You can run the app locally without an Azure subscription, but you'll need one in order to deploy the application to the cloud.
trans-unit.target: You can run the app locally without an Azure subscription, but you'll need one in order to deploy the application to the cloud.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can [activate your MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mcid=A55E3C668) or [sign up for a free trial](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mcid=A55E3C668).
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can [activate your MSDN subscriber benefits](/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/?WT.mcid=A55E3C668) or [sign up for a free trial](/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mcid=A55E3C668).

trans-unit.source: The tutorial instructions work with either of the following products:
trans-unit.target: The tutorial instructions work with either of the following products:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web

trans-unit.source: If you don't have one of these, Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web will be installed automatically when you install the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have one of these, Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web will be installed automatically when you install the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: The app stores ads in a SQL database, using Entity Framework Code First to create the tables and access the data.
trans-unit.target: The app stores ads in a SQL database, using Entity Framework Code First to create the tables and access the data.

trans-unit.source: For each ad the database stores two URLs, one for the full-size image and one for the thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: For each ad the database stores two URLs, one for the full-size image and one for the thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Ad table</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Ad table</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When a user uploads an image, the front-end running in a web role stores the image in an <linkText>Azure blob</linkText><title></title>, and it stores the ad information in the database with a URL that points to the blob.
trans-unit.target: When a user uploads an image, the front-end running in a web role stores the image in an <linkText>Azure blob</linkText><title></title>, and it stores the ad information in the database with a URL that points to the blob.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, it writes a message to an Azure queue.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, it writes a message to an Azure queue.

trans-unit.source: A back-end process running in a worker role periodically polls the queue for new messages.
trans-unit.target: A back-end process running in a worker role periodically polls the queue for new messages.

trans-unit.source: When a new message appears, the worker role creates a thumbnail for that image and updates the thumbnail URL database field for that ad.
trans-unit.target: When a new message appears, the worker role creates a thumbnail for that image and updates the thumbnail URL database field for that ad.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram shows how the parts of the application interact.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram shows how the parts of the application interact.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contoso Ads architecture</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contoso Ads architecture</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Download and unzip the <linkText>completed solution</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Download and unzip the <linkText>completed solution</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: From the File menu choose Open Project, navigate to where you downloaded the solution, and then open the solution file.
trans-unit.target: From the File menu choose Open Project, navigate to where you downloaded the solution, and then open the solution file.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+SHIFT+B to build the solution.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+SHIFT+B to build the solution.

trans-unit.source: By default, Visual Studio automatically restores the NuGet package content, which was not included in the .zip file.
trans-unit.target: By default, Visual Studio automatically restores the NuGet package content, which was not included in the .zip file.

trans-unit.source: If the packages don't restore, install them manually by going to the Manage NuGet Packages for Solution dialog box and clicking the Restore button at the top right.
trans-unit.target: If the packages don't restore, install them manually by going to the Manage NuGet Packages for Solution dialog box and clicking the Restore button at the top right.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, make sure that ContosoAdsCloudService is selected as the startup project.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, make sure that ContosoAdsCloudService is selected as the startup project.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: When you run a cloud service project locally, Visual Studio automatically invokes the Azure compute emulator and Azure storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: When you run a cloud service project locally, Visual Studio automatically invokes the Azure compute emulator and Azure storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: The compute emulator uses your computer's resources to simulate the web role and worker role environments.
trans-unit.target: The compute emulator uses your computer's resources to simulate the web role and worker role environments.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator uses a <linkText>SQL Server Express LocalDB</linkText><title></title> database to simulate Azure cloud storage.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator uses a <linkText>SQL Server Express LocalDB</linkText><title></title> database to simulate Azure cloud storage.

trans-unit.source: The first time you run a cloud service project, it takes a minute or so for the emulators to start up.
trans-unit.target: The first time you run a cloud service project, it takes a minute or so for the emulators to start up.

trans-unit.source: When emulator startup is finished, the default browser opens to the application home page.
trans-unit.target: When emulator startup is finished, the default browser opens to the application home page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contoso Ads architecture</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contoso Ads architecture</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Create an Ad.
trans-unit.target: Click Create an Ad.

trans-unit.source: Enter some test data and select a .jpg image to upload, and then click Create.
trans-unit.target: Enter some test data and select a .jpg image to upload, and then click Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The app goes to the Index page, but it doesn't show a thumbnail for the new ad because that processing hasn't happened yet.
trans-unit.target: The app goes to the Index page, but it doesn't show a thumbnail for the new ad because that processing hasn't happened yet.

trans-unit.source: Wait a moment and then refresh the Index page to see the thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: Wait a moment and then refresh the Index page to see the thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Index page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Index page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Details for your ad to see the full-size image.
trans-unit.target: Click Details for your ad to see the full-size image.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Details page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Details page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You've been running the application entirely on your local computer, with no connection to the cloud.
trans-unit.target: You've been running the application entirely on your local computer, with no connection to the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator stores the queue and blob data in a SQL Server Express LocalDB database, and the application stores the ad data in another LocalDB database.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator stores the queue and blob data in a SQL Server Express LocalDB database, and the application stores the ad data in another LocalDB database.

trans-unit.source: Entity Framework Code First automatically created the ad database the first time the web app tried to access it.
trans-unit.target: Entity Framework Code First automatically created the ad database the first time the web app tried to access it.

trans-unit.source: In the following section you'll configure the solution to use Azure cloud resources for queues, blobs, and the application database when it runs in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: In the following section you'll configure the solution to use Azure cloud resources for queues, blobs, and the application database when it runs in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: If you wanted to continue to run locally but use cloud storage and database resources, you could do that; it's just a matter of setting connection strings, which you'll see how to do.
trans-unit.target: If you wanted to continue to run locally but use cloud storage and database resources, you could do that; it's just a matter of setting connection strings, which you'll see how to do.

trans-unit.source: You'll do the following steps to run the application in the cloud:
trans-unit.target: You'll do the following steps to run the application in the cloud:

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Configure the solution to use your Azure SQL database when it runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Configure the solution to use your Azure SQL database when it runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Configure the solution to use your Azure storage account when it runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Configure the solution to use your Azure storage account when it runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the project to your Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the project to your Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: An Azure cloud service is the environment the application will run in.
trans-unit.target: An Azure cloud service is the environment the application will run in.

trans-unit.source: In your browser, open the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, open the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click New > Compute > Cloud Service > Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: Click New > Compute > Cloud Service > Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: In the URL input box, enter a URL prefix.
trans-unit.target: In the URL input box, enter a URL prefix.

trans-unit.source: This URL has to be unique.
trans-unit.target: This URL has to be unique.

trans-unit.source: You'll get an error message if the prefix you choose is already in use by someone else.
trans-unit.target: You'll get an error message if the prefix you choose is already in use by someone else.

trans-unit.source: Choose the region where you want to deploy the application.
trans-unit.target: Choose the region where you want to deploy the application.

trans-unit.source: This field specifies which datacenter your cloud service will be hosted in.
trans-unit.target: This field specifies which datacenter your cloud service will be hosted in.

trans-unit.source: For a production application, you'd choose the region closest to your customers.
trans-unit.target: For a production application, you'd choose the region closest to your customers.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, choose the region closest to you.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, choose the region closest to you.

trans-unit.source: Click Create Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: Click Create Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: In the following image, a cloud service is created with the URL contosoads.cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: In the following image, a cloud service is created with the URL contosoads.cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Cloud Service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Cloud Service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the app runs in the cloud, it will use a cloud-based database.
trans-unit.target: When the app runs in the cloud, it will use a cloud-based database.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, click New > Data Services > SQL Database > Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, click New > Data Services > SQL Database > Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: In the Database Name box, enter contosoads.
trans-unit.target: In the Database Name box, enter contosoads.

trans-unit.source: From the Server drop-down list, choose New SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: From the Server drop-down list, choose New SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, if your subscription already has a server, you can select that server from the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, if your subscription already has a server, you can select that server from the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: Choose the same Region that you chose for the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Choose the same Region that you chose for the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: When the cloud service and database are in different datacenters (different regions), latency will increase and you will be charged for bandwidth outside the data center.
trans-unit.target: When the cloud service and database are in different datacenters (different regions), latency will increase and you will be charged for bandwidth outside the data center.

trans-unit.source: Bandwidth within a data center is free.
trans-unit.target: Bandwidth within a data center is free.

trans-unit.source: Enter an administrator Login Name and Password.
trans-unit.target: Enter an administrator Login Name and Password.

trans-unit.source: If you selected New SQL Database server you aren't entering an existing name and password here, you're entering a new name and password that you're defining now to use later when you access the database.
trans-unit.target: If you selected New SQL Database server you aren't entering an existing name and password here, you're entering a new name and password that you're defining now to use later when you access the database.

trans-unit.source: If you selected a server that you created previously, you'll be prompted for the password to the administrative user account you already created.
trans-unit.target: If you selected a server that you created previously, you'll be prompted for the password to the administrative user account you already created.

trans-unit.source: Click Create SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Click Create SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New SQL Database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New SQL Database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After Azure finishes creating the database, click the SQL Databases tab in the left pane of the portal, and then click the name of the new database.
trans-unit.target: After Azure finishes creating the database, click the SQL Databases tab in the left pane of the portal, and then click the name of the new database.

trans-unit.source: Click the Dashboard tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the Dashboard tab.

trans-unit.source: Click Manage allowed IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: Click Manage allowed IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: Under Allowed Services, change Azure Services to Yes.
trans-unit.target: Under Allowed Services, change Azure Services to Yes.

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage account provides resources for storing queue and blob data in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage account provides resources for storing queue and blob data in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: In a real-world application, you would typically create separate accounts for application data versus logging data, and separate accounts for test data versus production data.
trans-unit.target: In a real-world application, you would typically create separate accounts for application data versus logging data, and separate accounts for test data versus production data.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial you'll use just one account.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial you'll use just one account.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, click New > Data Services > Storage > Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, click New > Data Services > Storage > Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: In the URL box, enter a URL prefix.
trans-unit.target: In the URL box, enter a URL prefix.

trans-unit.source: This prefix plus the text you see under the box will be the unique URL to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: This prefix plus the text you see under the box will be the unique URL to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: If the prefix you enter has already been used by someone else, you'll have to choose a different prefix.
trans-unit.target: If the prefix you enter has already been used by someone else, you'll have to choose a different prefix.

trans-unit.source: Set the Region drop-down list to the same region you chose for the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Set the Region drop-down list to the same region you chose for the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: When the cloud service and storage account are in different datacenters (different regions), latency will increase and you will be charged for bandwidth outside the data center.
trans-unit.target: When the cloud service and storage account are in different datacenters (different regions), latency will increase and you will be charged for bandwidth outside the data center.

trans-unit.source: Bandwidth within a data center is free.
trans-unit.target: Bandwidth within a data center is free.

trans-unit.source: Azure affinity groups provide a mechanism to minimize the distance between resources in a data center, which can reduce latency.
trans-unit.target: Azure affinity groups provide a mechanism to minimize the distance between resources in a data center, which can reduce latency.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial does not use affinity groups.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial does not use affinity groups.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>How to Create an Affinity Group in Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>How to Create an Affinity Group in Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Set the Replication drop-down list to Locally redundant.
trans-unit.target: Set the Replication drop-down list to Locally redundant.

trans-unit.source: When geo-replication is enabled for a storage account, the stored content is replicated to a secondary datacenter to enable failover to that location in case of a major disaster in the primary location.
trans-unit.target: When geo-replication is enabled for a storage account, the stored content is replicated to a secondary datacenter to enable failover to that location in case of a major disaster in the primary location.

trans-unit.source: Geo-replication can incur additional costs.
trans-unit.target: Geo-replication can incur additional costs.

trans-unit.source: For test and development accounts, you generally don't want to pay for geo-replication.
trans-unit.target: For test and development accounts, you generally don't want to pay for geo-replication.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click Create Storage Account.
trans-unit.target: Click Create Storage Account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the image, a storage account is created with the URL contosoads.core.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: In the image, a storage account is created with the URL contosoads.core.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: The web project and the worker role project each has its own database connection string, and each needs to point to the Azure SQL database when the app runs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The web project and the worker role project each has its own database connection string, and each needs to point to the Azure SQL database when the app runs in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You'll use a <linkText>Web.config transform</linkText><title></title> for the web role and a cloud service environment setting for the worker role.
trans-unit.target: You'll use a <linkText>Web.config transform</linkText><title></title> for the web role and a cloud service environment setting for the worker role.

trans-unit.source: In this section and the next section you store credentials in project files.
trans-unit.target: In this section and the next section you store credentials in project files.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Don't store sensitive data in public source code repositories</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Don't store sensitive data in public source code repositories</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, open the Web.Release.config transform file for the application Web.config file, delete the comment block that contains a element, and paste the following code in its place.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, open the Web.Release.config transform file for the application Web.config file, delete the comment block that contains a element, and paste the following code in its place.

trans-unit.source: Leave the file open for editing.
trans-unit.target: Leave the file open for editing.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, click SQL Databases in the left pane, click the database you created for this tutorial, click the Dashboard tab, and then click Show connection strings.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, click SQL Databases in the left pane, click the database you created for this tutorial, click the Dashboard tab, and then click Show connection strings.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Show connection strings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Show connection strings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The portal displays connection strings, with a placeholder for the password.
trans-unit.target: The portal displays connection strings, with a placeholder for the password.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connection strings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connection strings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Web.Release.config transform file, delete {connectionstring} and paste in its place the ADO.NET connection string from the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: In the Web.Release.config transform file, delete {connectionstring} and paste in its place the ADO.NET connection string from the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: In the connection string that you pasted into the Web.Release.config transform file, replace {your_password_here} with the password you created for the new SQL database.
trans-unit.target: In the connection string that you pasted into the Web.Release.config transform file, replace {your_password_here} with the password you created for the new SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: Select and copy the connection string (without the surrounding quotation marks) for use in the following steps for configuring the worker role project.
trans-unit.target: Select and copy the connection string (without the surrounding quotation marks) for use in the following steps for configuring the worker role project.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, under Roles in the cloud service project, right-click ContosoAdsWorker and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, under Roles in the cloud service project, right-click ContosoAdsWorker and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Role properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Role properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings tab.

trans-unit.source: Change Service Configuration to Cloud.
trans-unit.target: Change Service Configuration to Cloud.

trans-unit.source: Select the text in the ContosoAdsDbConnectionString setting, and then paste the connection string that you copied from the previous section of the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Select the text in the ContosoAdsDbConnectionString setting, and then paste the connection string that you copied from the previous section of the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Database connection string for worker role</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Database connection string for worker role</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: Azure storage account connection strings for both the web role project and the worker role project are stored in environment settings in the cloud service project.
trans-unit.target: Azure storage account connection strings for both the web role project and the worker role project are stored in environment settings in the cloud service project.

trans-unit.source: For each project there is a separate set of settings to be used when the application runs locally and when it runs in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: For each project there is a separate set of settings to be used when the application runs locally and when it runs in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: You'll update the cloud environment settings for both web and worker role projects.
trans-unit.target: You'll update the cloud environment settings for both web and worker role projects.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click ContosoAdsWeb under Roles in the ContosoAdsCloudService project, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click ContosoAdsWeb under Roles in the ContosoAdsCloudService project, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Role properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Role properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings tab.

trans-unit.source: In the Service Configuration drop-down box, choose Cloud.
trans-unit.target: In the Service Configuration drop-down box, choose Cloud.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Cloud configuration</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Cloud configuration</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the StorageConnectionString entry, and you'll see an ellipsis (...) button at the right end of the line.
trans-unit.target: Select the StorageConnectionString entry, and you'll see an ellipsis (...) button at the right end of the line.

trans-unit.source: Click the ellipsis button to open the Create Storage Account Connection String dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click the ellipsis button to open the Create Storage Account Connection String dialog box.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Open Connection String Create box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Open Connection String Create box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create Storage Connection String dialog box, click Your subscription, choose the storage account that you created earlier, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Storage Connection String dialog box, click Your subscription, choose the storage account that you created earlier, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: If you're not already logged in, you'll be prompted for your Azure account credentials.
trans-unit.target: If you're not already logged in, you'll be prompted for your Azure account credentials.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create Storage Connection String</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create Storage Connection String</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: Follow the same procedure that you used for the StorageConnectionString connection string to set the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Plugins.Diagnostics.ConnectionString connection string.
trans-unit.target: Follow the same procedure that you used for the StorageConnectionString connection string to set the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Plugins.Diagnostics.ConnectionString connection string.

trans-unit.source: This connection string is used for logging.
trans-unit.target: This connection string is used for logging.

trans-unit.source: Follow the same procedure that you used for the ContosoAdsWeb role to set both connection strings for the ContosoAdsWorker role.
trans-unit.target: Follow the same procedure that you used for the ContosoAdsWeb role to set both connection strings for the ContosoAdsWorker role.

trans-unit.source: Don't forget to set Service Configuration to Cloud.
trans-unit.target: Don't forget to set Service Configuration to Cloud.

trans-unit.source: The role environment settings that you have configured using the Visual Studio UI are stored in the following files in the ContosoAdsCloudService project:
trans-unit.target: The role environment settings that you have configured using the Visual Studio UI are stored in the following files in the ContosoAdsCloudService project:

trans-unit.source: ServiceDefinition.csdef - Defines the setting names.
trans-unit.target: ServiceDefinition.csdef - Defines the setting names.

trans-unit.source: ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg - Provides values for when the app runs in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg - Provides values for when the app runs in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: ServiceConfiguration.Local.cscfg - Provides values for when the app runs locally.
trans-unit.target: ServiceConfiguration.Local.cscfg - Provides values for when the app runs locally.

trans-unit.source: For example, the ServiceDefinition.csdef includes the following definitions.
trans-unit.target: For example, the ServiceDefinition.csdef includes the following definitions.

trans-unit.source: And the ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg file includes the values you entered for those settings in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: And the ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg file includes the values you entered for those settings in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: The setting specifies the number of virtual machines that Azure will run the worker role code on. The Next steps section includes links to more information about scaling out a cloud service,
trans-unit.target: The setting specifies the number of virtual machines that Azure will run the worker role code on. The Next steps section includes links to more information about scaling out a cloud service,

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ContosoAdsCloudService cloud project and then select Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the ContosoAdsCloudService cloud project and then select Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Sign in step of the Publish Azure Application wizard, click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Sign in step of the Publish Azure Application wizard, click Next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Sign in step</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Sign in step</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Settings step of the wizard, click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Settings step of the wizard, click Next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Settings step</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Settings step</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The default settings in the Advanced tab are fine for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The default settings in the Advanced tab are fine for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: For information about the advanced tab, see <linkText>Publish Azure Application Wizard</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about the advanced tab, see <linkText>Publish Azure Application Wizard</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the Summary step, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In the Summary step, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Summary step</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Summary step</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Azure Activity Log window opens in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Activity Log window opens in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Click the right arrow icon to expand the deployment details.
trans-unit.target: Click the right arrow icon to expand the deployment details.

trans-unit.source: The deployment can take up to 5 minutes or more to complete.
trans-unit.target: The deployment can take up to 5 minutes or more to complete.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Activity Log window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Activity Log window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the deployment status is complete, click the Website URL to start the application.
trans-unit.target: When the deployment status is complete, click the Website URL to start the application.

trans-unit.source: You can now test the app by creating, viewing, and editing some ads, as you did when you ran the application locally.
trans-unit.target: You can now test the app by creating, viewing, and editing some ads, as you did when you ran the application locally.

trans-unit.source: When you're finished testing, delete or stop the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: When you're finished testing, delete or stop the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Even if you're not using the cloud service, it's accruing charges because virtual machine resources are reserved for it.
trans-unit.target: Even if you're not using the cloud service, it's accruing charges because virtual machine resources are reserved for it.

trans-unit.source: And if you leave it running, anyone who finds your URL can create and view ads.
trans-unit.target: And if you leave it running, anyone who finds your URL can create and view ads.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, go to the Dashboard tab for your cloud service, and then click the Delete button at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, go to the Dashboard tab for your cloud service, and then click the Delete button at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If you just want to temporarily prevent others from accessing the site, click Stop instead.
trans-unit.target: If you just want to temporarily prevent others from accessing the site, click Stop instead.

trans-unit.source: In that case, charges will continue to accrue.
trans-unit.target: In that case, charges will continue to accrue.

trans-unit.source: You can follow a similar procedure to delete the SQL database and storage account when you no longer need them.
trans-unit.target: You can follow a similar procedure to delete the SQL database and storage account when you no longer need them.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already downloaded <linkText>the completed application</linkText><title></title>, do that now.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already downloaded <linkText>the completed application</linkText><title></title>, do that now.

trans-unit.source: You'll copy files from the downloaded project into the new project.
trans-unit.target: You'll copy files from the downloaded project into the new project.

trans-unit.source: Creating the Contoso Ads application involves the following steps:
trans-unit.target: Creating the Contoso Ads application involves the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Create a cloud service Visual Studio solution.
trans-unit.target: Create a cloud service Visual Studio solution.

trans-unit.source: Update and add NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: Update and add NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: Set project references.
trans-unit.target: Set project references.

trans-unit.source: Configure connection strings.
trans-unit.target: Configure connection strings.

trans-unit.source: Add code files.
trans-unit.target: Add code files.

trans-unit.source: After the solution is created, you'll review the code that is unique to cloud service projects and Azure blobs and queues.
trans-unit.target: After the solution is created, you'll review the code that is unique to cloud service projects and Azure blobs and queues.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, choose New Project from the File menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, choose New Project from the File menu.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of the New Project dialog box, expand Visual C# and choose Cloud templates, and then choose the Azure Cloud Service template.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of the New Project dialog box, expand Visual C# and choose Cloud templates, and then choose the Azure Cloud Service template.

trans-unit.source: Name the project and solution ContosoAdsCloudService, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Name the project and solution ContosoAdsCloudService, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Project</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Project</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New Azure Cloud Service dialog box, add a web role and a worker role.
trans-unit.target: In the New Azure Cloud Service dialog box, add a web role and a worker role.

trans-unit.source: Name the web role ContosoAdsWeb, and name the worker role ContosoAdsWorker.
trans-unit.target: Name the web role ContosoAdsWeb, and name the worker role ContosoAdsWorker.

trans-unit.source: (Use the pencil icon in the right-hand pane to change the default names of the roles.)
trans-unit.target: (Use the pencil icon in the right-hand pane to change the default names of the roles.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Cloud Service Project</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Cloud Service Project</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When you see the New ASP.NET Project dialog box for the web role, choose the MVC template, and then click Change Authentication.
trans-unit.target: When you see the New ASP.NET Project dialog box for the web role, choose the MVC template, and then click Change Authentication.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Change Authentication</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Change Authentication</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Change Authentication dialog box, choose No Authentication, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Change Authentication dialog box, choose No Authentication, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>No Authentication</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>No Authentication</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog, click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog, click OK.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the solution (not one of the projects), and choose Add - New Project.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the solution (not one of the projects), and choose Add - New Project.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Project dialog box, choose Windows Desktop under Visual C# in the left pane, and then click the Class Library template.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Project dialog box, choose Windows Desktop under Visual C# in the left pane, and then click the Class Library template.

trans-unit.source: Name the project ContosoAdsCommon, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Name the project ContosoAdsCommon, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: You need to reference the Entity Framework context and the data model from both web and worker role projects.
trans-unit.target: You need to reference the Entity Framework context and the data model from both web and worker role projects.

trans-unit.source: As an alternative you could define the EF-related classes in the web role project and reference that project from the worker role project.
trans-unit.target: As an alternative you could define the EF-related classes in the web role project and reference that project from the worker role project.

trans-unit.source: But in the alternative approach, your worker role project would have a reference to web assemblies which it doesn't need.
trans-unit.target: But in the alternative approach, your worker role project would have a reference to web assemblies which it doesn't need.

trans-unit.source: Open the Manage NuGet Packages dialog box for the solution.
trans-unit.target: Open the Manage NuGet Packages dialog box for the solution.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, select Updates.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, select Updates.

trans-unit.source: Look for the WindowsAzure.Storage package, and if it's in the list, click Update to get the latest version of the storage client library.
trans-unit.target: Look for the WindowsAzure.Storage package, and if it's in the list, click Update to get the latest version of the storage client library.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Update SCL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Update SCL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The storage client library is updated more frequently than Visual Studio project templates, so you'll often find that the version in a newly created projected needs to be updated.
trans-unit.target: The storage client library is updated more frequently than Visual Studio project templates, so you'll often find that the version in a newly created projected needs to be updated.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, select Online.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, select Online.

trans-unit.source: Find the EntityFramework NuGet package, and install it in all three projects.
trans-unit.target: Find the EntityFramework NuGet package, and install it in all three projects.

trans-unit.source: Find the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ConfigurationManager NuGet package, and install it in the worker role project.
trans-unit.target: Find the Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ConfigurationManager NuGet package, and install it in the worker role project.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, set a reference to the ContosoAdsCommon project.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, set a reference to the ContosoAdsCommon project.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the ContosoAdsWeb project, and then click References - Add References.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the ContosoAdsWeb project, and then click References - Add References.

trans-unit.source: In the Reference Manager dialog box, select Solution – Projects in the left pane, select ContosoAdsCommon, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Reference Manager dialog box, select Solution – Projects in the left pane, select ContosoAdsCommon, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWorker project, set a reference to the ContosAdsCommon project.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWorker project, set a reference to the ContosAdsCommon project.

trans-unit.source: ContosoAdsCommon will contain the Entity Framework data model and context class, which will be used by both the front-end and back-end.
trans-unit.target: ContosoAdsCommon will contain the Entity Framework data model and context class, which will be used by both the front-end and back-end.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWorker project, set a reference to System.Drawing.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWorker project, set a reference to System.Drawing.

trans-unit.source: This assembly is used by the back-end to convert images to thumbnails.
trans-unit.target: This assembly is used by the back-end to convert images to thumbnails.

trans-unit.source: In this section you configure Azure Storage and SQL connection strings for testing locally.
trans-unit.target: In this section you configure Azure Storage and SQL connection strings for testing locally.

trans-unit.source: The deployment instructions earlier in the tutorial explain how to set up the connection strings for when the app runs in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The deployment instructions earlier in the tutorial explain how to set up the connection strings for when the app runs in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, open the application Web.config file, and insert the following connectionStrings element after the configSections element.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, open the application Web.config file, and insert the following connectionStrings element after the configSections element.

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsCloudService project, right-click ContosoAdsWeb under Roles, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsCloudService project, right-click ContosoAdsWeb under Roles, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Role properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Role properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the ContosAdsWeb [Role] properties window, click the Settings tab, and then click Add Setting.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosAdsWeb [Role] properties window, click the Settings tab, and then click Add Setting.

trans-unit.source: Leave Service Configuration set to All Configurations.
trans-unit.target: Leave Service Configuration set to All Configurations.

trans-unit.source: Add a new setting named StorageConnectionString.
trans-unit.target: Add a new setting named StorageConnectionString.

trans-unit.source: Set Type to ConnectionString, and set Value to UseDevelopmentStorage=true.
trans-unit.target: Set Type to ConnectionString, and set Value to UseDevelopmentStorage=true.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New connection string</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New connection string</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: Follow the same procedure to add a storage connection string in the ContosoAdsWorker role properties.
trans-unit.target: Follow the same procedure to add a storage connection string in the ContosoAdsWorker role properties.

trans-unit.source: Still in the ContosoAdsWorker [Role] properties window, add another connection string:
trans-unit.target: Still in the ContosoAdsWorker [Role] properties window, add another connection string:

trans-unit.source: Name: ContosoAdsDbConnectionString
trans-unit.target: Name: ContosoAdsDbConnectionString

trans-unit.source: Type: String
trans-unit.target: Type: String

trans-unit.source: Value: Paste the same connection string you used for the web role project:
trans-unit.target: Value: Paste the same connection string you used for the web role project:

trans-unit.source: In this section you copy code files from the downloaded solution into the new solution.
trans-unit.target: In this section you copy code files from the downloaded solution into the new solution.

trans-unit.source: The following sections will show and explain key parts of this code.
trans-unit.target: The following sections will show and explain key parts of this code.

trans-unit.source: To add files to a project or a folder, right-click the project or folder and click Add - Existing Item.
trans-unit.target: To add files to a project or a folder, right-click the project or folder and click Add - Existing Item.

trans-unit.source: Select the files you want and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Select the files you want and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: If asked whether you want to replace existing files, click Yes.
trans-unit.target: If asked whether you want to replace existing files, click Yes.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsCommon project, delete the Class1.cs file and add in its place the Ad.cs and ContosoAdscontext.cs files from the downloaded project.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsCommon project, delete the Class1.cs file and add in its place the Ad.cs and ContosoAdscontext.cs files from the downloaded project.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, add the following files from the downloaded project.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWeb project, add the following files from the downloaded project.

trans-unit.source: Global.asax.cs.
trans-unit.target: Global.asax.cs.

trans-unit.source: In the Views\Shared folder: \_Layout.cshtml.
trans-unit.target: In the Views\Shared folder: \_Layout.cshtml.

trans-unit.source: In the Views\Home folder: Index.cshtml.
trans-unit.target: In the Views\Home folder: Index.cshtml.

trans-unit.source: In the Controllers folder: AdController.cs.
trans-unit.target: In the Controllers folder: AdController.cs.

trans-unit.source: In the Views\Ad folder (create the folder first): five .cshtml files.
trans-unit.target: In the Views\Ad folder (create the folder first): five .cshtml files.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWorker project, add WorkerRole.cs from the downloaded project.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWorker project, add WorkerRole.cs from the downloaded project.

trans-unit.source: You can now build and run the application as instructed earlier in the tutorial, and the app will use local database and storage emulator resources.
trans-unit.target: You can now build and run the application as instructed earlier in the tutorial, and the app will use local database and storage emulator resources.

trans-unit.source: The following sections explain the code related to working with the Azure environment, blobs, and queues.
trans-unit.target: The following sections explain the code related to working with the Azure environment, blobs, and queues.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial does not explain how to create MVC controllers and views using scaffolding, how to write Entity Framework code that works with SQL Server databases, or the basics of asynchronous programming in ASP.NET 4.5.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial does not explain how to create MVC controllers and views using scaffolding, how to write Entity Framework code that works with SQL Server databases, or the basics of asynchronous programming in ASP.NET 4.5.

trans-unit.source: For information about these topics, see the following resources:
trans-unit.target: For information about these topics, see the following resources:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get started with MVC 5</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get started with MVC 5</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get started with EF 6 and MVC 5</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get started with EF 6 and MVC 5</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Introduction to asynchronous programming in .NET 4.5</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Introduction to asynchronous programming in .NET 4.5</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Ad.cs file defines an enum for ad categories and a POCO entity class for ad information.
trans-unit.target: The Ad.cs file defines an enum for ad categories and a POCO entity class for ad information.

trans-unit.source: The ContosoAdsContext class specifies that the Ad class is used in a DbSet collection, which Entity Framework will store in a SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The ContosoAdsContext class specifies that the Ad class is used in a DbSet collection, which Entity Framework will store in a SQL database.

trans-unit.source: The class has two constructors.
trans-unit.target: The class has two constructors.

trans-unit.source: The first of them is used by the web project, and specifies the name of a connection string that is stored in the Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: The first of them is used by the web project, and specifies the name of a connection string that is stored in the Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: The second constructor enables you to pass in the actual connection string.
trans-unit.target: The second constructor enables you to pass in the actual connection string.

trans-unit.source: That is needed by the worker role project, since it doesn't have a Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: That is needed by the worker role project, since it doesn't have a Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: You saw earlier where this connection string was stored, and you'll see later how the code retrieves the connection string when it instantiates the DbContext class.
trans-unit.target: You saw earlier where this connection string was stored, and you'll see later how the code retrieves the connection string when it instantiates the DbContext class.

trans-unit.source: Code that is called from the Application_Start method creates an images blob container and an images queue if they don't already exist.
trans-unit.target: Code that is called from the Application_Start method creates an images blob container and an images queue if they don't already exist.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that whenever you start using a new storage account, or start using the storage emulator on a new computer, the required blob container and queue will be created automatically.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that whenever you start using a new storage account, or start using the storage emulator on a new computer, the required blob container and queue will be created automatically.

trans-unit.source: The code gets access to the storage account by using the storage connection string from the .cscfg file.
trans-unit.target: The code gets access to the storage account by using the storage connection string from the .cscfg file.

trans-unit.source: Then it gets a reference to the images blob container, creates the container if it doesn't already exist, and sets access permissions on the new container.
trans-unit.target: Then it gets a reference to the images blob container, creates the container if it doesn't already exist, and sets access permissions on the new container.

trans-unit.source: By default, new containers only allow clients with storage account credentials to access blobs.
trans-unit.target: By default, new containers only allow clients with storage account credentials to access blobs.

trans-unit.source: The website needs the blobs to be public so that it can display images using URLs that point to the image blobs.
trans-unit.target: The website needs the blobs to be public so that it can display images using URLs that point to the image blobs.

trans-unit.source: Similar code gets a reference to the images queue and creates a new queue.
trans-unit.target: Similar code gets a reference to the images queue and creates a new queue.

trans-unit.source: In this case no permissions change is needed.
trans-unit.target: In this case no permissions change is needed.

trans-unit.source: The _Layout.cshtml file sets the app name in the header and footer, and creates an "Ads" menu entry.
trans-unit.target: The _Layout.cshtml file sets the app name in the header and footer, and creates an "Ads" menu entry.

trans-unit.source: The Views\Home\Index.cshtml file displays category links on the home page.
trans-unit.target: The Views\Home\Index.cshtml file displays category links on the home page.

trans-unit.source: The links pass the integer value of the Category enum in a querystring variable to the Ads Index page.
trans-unit.target: The links pass the integer value of the Category enum in a querystring variable to the Ads Index page.

trans-unit.source: In the AdController.cs file the constructor calls the InitializeStorage method to create Azure Storage Client Library objects that provide an API for working with blobs and queues.
trans-unit.target: In the AdController.cs file the constructor calls the InitializeStorage method to create Azure Storage Client Library objects that provide an API for working with blobs and queues.

trans-unit.source: Then the code gets a reference to the images blob container as you saw earlier in Global.asax.cs.
trans-unit.target: Then the code gets a reference to the images blob container as you saw earlier in Global.asax.cs.

trans-unit.source: While doing that it sets a default <linkText>retry policy</linkText><title></title> appropriate for a web app.
trans-unit.target: While doing that it sets a default <linkText>retry policy</linkText><title></title> appropriate for a web app.

trans-unit.source: The default exponential backoff retry policy could hang the web app for longer than a minute on repeated retries for a transient fault.
trans-unit.target: The default exponential backoff retry policy could hang the web app for longer than a minute on repeated retries for a transient fault.

trans-unit.source: The retry policy specified here waits 3 seconds after each try for up to 3 tries.
trans-unit.target: The retry policy specified here waits 3 seconds after each try for up to 3 tries.

trans-unit.source: Similar code gets a reference to the images queue.
trans-unit.target: Similar code gets a reference to the images queue.

trans-unit.source: Most of the controller code is typical for working with an Entity Framework data model using a DbContext class.
trans-unit.target: Most of the controller code is typical for working with an Entity Framework data model using a DbContext class.

trans-unit.source: An exception is the HttpPost Create method, which uploads a file and saves it in blob storage.
trans-unit.target: An exception is the HttpPost Create method, which uploads a file and saves it in blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The model binder provides an <linkText>HttpPostedFileBase</linkText><title></title> object to the method.
trans-unit.target: The model binder provides an <linkText>HttpPostedFileBase</linkText><title></title> object to the method.

trans-unit.source: If the user selected a file to upload, the code uploads the file, saves it in a blob, and updates the Ad database record with a URL that points to the blob.
trans-unit.target: If the user selected a file to upload, the code uploads the file, saves it in a blob, and updates the Ad database record with a URL that points to the blob.

trans-unit.source: The code that does the upload is in the UploadAndSaveBlobAsync method.
trans-unit.target: The code that does the upload is in the UploadAndSaveBlobAsync method.

trans-unit.source: It creates a GUID name for the blob, uploads and saves the file, and returns a reference to the saved blob.
trans-unit.target: It creates a GUID name for the blob, uploads and saves the file, and returns a reference to the saved blob.

trans-unit.source: After the HttpPost Create method uploads a blob and updates the database, it creates a queue message to inform that back-end process that an image is ready for conversion to a thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: After the HttpPost Create method uploads a blob and updates the database, it creates a queue message to inform that back-end process that an image is ready for conversion to a thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: The code for the HttpPost Edit method is similar except that if the user selects a new image file any blobs that already exist must be deleted.
trans-unit.target: The code for the HttpPost Edit method is similar except that if the user selects a new image file any blobs that already exist must be deleted.

trans-unit.source: The next example shows the code that deletes blobs when you delete an ad.
trans-unit.target: The next example shows the code that deletes blobs when you delete an ad.

trans-unit.source: The Index.cshtml file displays thumbnails with the other ad data.
trans-unit.target: The Index.cshtml file displays thumbnails with the other ad data.

trans-unit.source: The Details.cshtml file displays the full-size image.
trans-unit.target: The Details.cshtml file displays the full-size image.

trans-unit.source: The Create.cshtml and Edit.cshtml files specify form encoding that enables the controller to get the HttpPostedFileBase object.
trans-unit.target: The Create.cshtml and Edit.cshtml files specify form encoding that enables the controller to get the HttpPostedFileBase object.

trans-unit.source: An element tells the browser to provide a file selection dialog.
trans-unit.target: An element tells the browser to provide a file selection dialog.

trans-unit.source: The Azure worker role environment calls the OnStart method in the WorkerRole class when the worker role is getting started, and it calls the Run method when the OnStart method finishes.
trans-unit.target: The Azure worker role environment calls the OnStart method in the WorkerRole class when the worker role is getting started, and it calls the Run method when the OnStart method finishes.

trans-unit.source: The OnStart method gets the database connection string from the .cscfg file and passes it to the Entity Framework DbContext class.
trans-unit.target: The OnStart method gets the database connection string from the .cscfg file and passes it to the Entity Framework DbContext class.

trans-unit.source: The SQLClient provider is used by default, so the provider does not have to be specified.
trans-unit.target: The SQLClient provider is used by default, so the provider does not have to be specified.

trans-unit.source: After that the method gets a reference to the storage account and creates the blob container and queue if they don't exist.
trans-unit.target: After that the method gets a reference to the storage account and creates the blob container and queue if they don't exist.

trans-unit.source: The code for that is similar to what you already saw in the web role Application_Start method.
trans-unit.target: The code for that is similar to what you already saw in the web role Application_Start method.

trans-unit.source: The Run method is called when the OnStart method finishes its initialization work.
trans-unit.target: The Run method is called when the OnStart method finishes its initialization work.

trans-unit.source: The method executes an infinite loop that watches for new queue messages and processes them when they arrive.
trans-unit.target: The method executes an infinite loop that watches for new queue messages and processes them when they arrive.

trans-unit.source: After each iteration of the loop, if no queue message was found, the program sleeps for a second.
trans-unit.target: After each iteration of the loop, if no queue message was found, the program sleeps for a second.

trans-unit.source: This prevents the worker role from incurring excessive CPU time and storage transaction costs.
trans-unit.target: This prevents the worker role from incurring excessive CPU time and storage transaction costs.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Customer Advisory Team tells a story about a developer who forgot to include this, deployed to production, and left for vacation.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Customer Advisory Team tells a story about a developer who forgot to include this, deployed to production, and left for vacation.

trans-unit.source: When he got back, his oversight cost more than the vacation.
trans-unit.target: When he got back, his oversight cost more than the vacation.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes the content of a queue message causes an error in processing.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes the content of a queue message causes an error in processing.

trans-unit.source: This is called a poison message, and if you just logged an error and restarted the loop, you could endlessly try to process that message.
trans-unit.target: This is called a poison message, and if you just logged an error and restarted the loop, you could endlessly try to process that message.

trans-unit.source: Therefore the catch block includes an if statement that checks to see how many times the app has tried to process the current message, and if it has been more than 5 times, the message is deleted from the queue.
trans-unit.target: Therefore the catch block includes an if statement that checks to see how many times the app has tried to process the current message, and if it has been more than 5 times, the message is deleted from the queue.

trans-unit.source: ProcessQueueMessage is called when a queue message is found.
trans-unit.target: ProcessQueueMessage is called when a queue message is found.

trans-unit.source: This code reads the database to get the image URL, converts the image to a thumbnail, saves the thumbnail in a blob, updates the database with the thumbnail blob URL, and deletes the queue message.
trans-unit.target: This code reads the database to get the image URL, converts the image to a thumbnail, saves the thumbnail in a blob, updates the database with the thumbnail blob URL, and deletes the queue message.

trans-unit.source: The code in the ConvertImageToThumbnailJPG method uses classes in the System.Drawing namespace for simplicity.
trans-unit.target: The code in the ConvertImageToThumbnailJPG method uses classes in the System.Drawing namespace for simplicity.

trans-unit.source: However, the classes in this namespace were designed for use with Windows Forms.
trans-unit.target: However, the classes in this namespace were designed for use with Windows Forms.

trans-unit.source: They are not supported for use in a Windows or ASP.NET service.
trans-unit.target: They are not supported for use in a Windows or ASP.NET service.

trans-unit.source: For more information about image processing options, see <linkText>Dynamic Image Generation</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Deep Inside Image Resizing</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about image processing options, see <linkText>Dynamic Image Generation</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Deep Inside Image Resizing</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In case something doesn't work while you're following the instructions in this tutorial, here are some common errors and how to resolve them.
trans-unit.target: In case something doesn't work while you're following the instructions in this tutorial, here are some common errors and how to resolve them.

trans-unit.source: The RoleEnvironment object is provided by Azure when you run an application in Azure or when you run locally using the Azure compute emulator.
trans-unit.target: The RoleEnvironment object is provided by Azure when you run an application in Azure or when you run locally using the Azure compute emulator.

trans-unit.source: If you get this error when you're running locally, make sure that you have set the ContosoAdsCloudService project as the startup project.
trans-unit.target: If you get this error when you're running locally, make sure that you have set the ContosoAdsCloudService project as the startup project.

trans-unit.source: This sets up the project to run using the Azure compute emulator.
trans-unit.target: This sets up the project to run using the Azure compute emulator.

trans-unit.source: One of the things the application uses the Azure RoleEnvironment for is to get the connection string values that are stored in the .cscfg files, so another cause of this exception is a missing connection string.
trans-unit.target: One of the things the application uses the Azure RoleEnvironment for is to get the connection string values that are stored in the .cscfg files, so another cause of this exception is a missing connection string.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you created the StorageConnectionString setting for both Cloud and Local configurations in the ContosoAdsWeb project, and that you created both connection strings for both configurations in the ContosoAdsWorker project.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you created the StorageConnectionString setting for both Cloud and Local configurations in the ContosoAdsWeb project, and that you created both connection strings for both configurations in the ContosoAdsWorker project.

trans-unit.source: If you do a Find All search for StorageConnectionString in the entire solution, you should see it 9 times in 6 files.
trans-unit.target: If you do a Find All search for StorageConnectionString in the entire solution, you should see it 9 times in 6 files.

trans-unit.source: Try changing the port number used by the web project.
trans-unit.target: Try changing the port number used by the web project.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the ContosoAdsWeb project, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the ContosoAdsWeb project, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: Click the Web tab, and then change the port number in the Project Url setting.
trans-unit.target: Click the Web tab, and then change the port number in the Project Url setting.

trans-unit.source: For another alternative that might resolve the problem, see the following section.
trans-unit.target: For another alternative that might resolve the problem, see the following section.

trans-unit.source: By default new cloud service projects use the Azure compute emulator express to simulate the Azure environment.
trans-unit.target: By default new cloud service projects use the Azure compute emulator express to simulate the Azure environment.

trans-unit.source: This is a lightweight version of the full compute emulator, and under some conditions the full emulator will work when the express version does not.
trans-unit.target: This is a lightweight version of the full compute emulator, and under some conditions the full emulator will work when the express version does not.

trans-unit.source: To change the project to use the full emulator, right-click the ContosoAdsCloudService project, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: To change the project to use the full emulator, right-click the ContosoAdsCloudService project, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the Properties window click the Web tab, and then click the Use Full Emulator radio button.
trans-unit.target: In the Properties window click the Web tab, and then click the Use Full Emulator radio button.

trans-unit.source: In order to run the application with the full emulator, you have to open Visual Studio with administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: In order to run the application with the full emulator, you have to open Visual Studio with administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: The Contoso Ads application has intentionally been kept simple for a getting-started tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The Contoso Ads application has intentionally been kept simple for a getting-started tutorial.

trans-unit.source: For example, it doesn't implement <linkText>dependency injection</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>repository and unit of work patterns</linkText><title></title>, it doesn't <linkText>use an interface for logging</linkText><title></title>, it doesn't use <linkText>EF Code First Migrations</linkText><title></title> to manage data model changes or <linkText>EF Connection Resiliency</linkText><title></title> to manage transient network errors, and so forth.
trans-unit.target: For example, it doesn't implement <linkText>dependency injection</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>repository and unit of work patterns</linkText><title></title>, it doesn't <linkText>use an interface for logging</linkText><title></title>, it doesn't use <linkText>EF Code First Migrations</linkText><title></title> to manage data model changes or <linkText>EF Connection Resiliency</linkText><title></title> to manage transient network errors, and so forth.

trans-unit.source: Here are some cloud service sample applications that demonstrate more real-world coding practices, listed from less complex to more complex:
trans-unit.target: Here are some cloud service sample applications that demonstrate more real-world coding practices, listed from less complex to more complex:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>PhluffyFotos</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>PhluffyFotos</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Similar in concept to Contoso Ads but implements more features and more real-world coding practices.
trans-unit.target: Similar in concept to Contoso Ads but implements more features and more real-world coding practices.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Cloud Service Multi-Tier Application with Tables, Queues, and Blobs</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Cloud Service Multi-Tier Application with Tables, Queues, and Blobs</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Introduces Azure Storage tables as well as blobs and queues, and comes with a <linkText>step-by-step tutorial series</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Introduces Azure Storage tables as well as blobs and queues, and comes with a <linkText>step-by-step tutorial series</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Cloud Service Fundamentals in Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Cloud Service Fundamentals in Microsoft Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A comprehensive sample demonstrating a wide range of best practices, produced by the Microsoft Patterns and Practices group.
trans-unit.target: A comprehensive sample demonstrating a wide range of best practices, produced by the Microsoft Patterns and Practices group.

trans-unit.source: For general information about developing for the cloud, see <linkText>Building Real-World Cloud Apps with Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For general information about developing for the cloud, see <linkText>Building Real-World Cloud Apps with Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For a video introduction to Azure Storage best practices and patterns, see <linkText>Microsoft Azure Storage – What's New, Best Practices and Patterns</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a video introduction to Azure Storage best practices and patterns, see <linkText>Microsoft Azure Storage – What's New, Best Practices and Patterns</linkText><title></title>.
